IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: To promote and foster a knowledge of art by providing facilities for exhibitions and programs to improve education in the arts.
IRS990.MissionDescription: The Plains Art Museum brings people and art together. As a public institution we celebrate the finest of human achievement and inspire and engage diverse audiences in the creation, exhibition, collection, and preservation of art.
IRS990.Description: In fiscal year 2010, Plains Art Museum served 42,746 visitors of all ages through high quality art exhibitions, educational programs, live music, and outreach activities. The museum organizes six to eight major exhibitions annually with an equal number of smaller exhibitions. The museum's permanent collection of 3,300 objects is also used for special exhibitions and research, occasionally shown in national and international venues. Exhibitions focus on artists in the community and region. The permanent collection focuses on 20th and 21st century American art, regional art, and work by Native American artists.In fiscal year 2010, the museum presented the following exhibitions:*Drawings by Frank Big Bear*Day of the Dead: Latino artists create steamroller prints*Stories of the Somali Diaspora: photographs by Abdi Roble*Individual to icon: Portraits of the famous and almost famous from folk art to facebook*16th annual national Juried Watermedia Exhibition*Modern Man presents: Andy, you used me*In addition, the museum presented a number of exhibitions in its ancillary spaces.

Activity2.Description: In-house education programs include docent-led tours, lectures, artist talks, curator-led gallery talks, internships, art camps and art classes and workshops for children and adults. Outreach programs, which brings original art exhibitions and art education programs to rural Minnesota and North Dakota.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Footnote from Audited Financial Statements regarding Financial Statement treatment of donated works of art: The Museum does not capitalize donated works of art or recognize them as revenues or gains. Donations need not be recognized if they are added to collections that are held for public exhibition, education, or research in furtherance of public service rather than financial gain; are protected, kept unencumbered, cared for, and preserved; and are subject to a policy that requires the proceeds from sales of collection items to be used to acquire other items for collections. Gifts received in 2010 and 2009 were valued at $605,600 and $490,600, respectively. Collection items are recorded at cost if purchased.

The Plains Art Museum's collections consist of over 3,800 fine art and ethnographic objects in both the museum's permanent and educational collections. The museum regularly exhibits and interprets objects from its permanent and education collections in one of the museum's primary galleries on a permanent, annual rotating basis. Additionally, temporary and/or travelling exhibitions hosted by the museum are often augmented and greatly enhanced by objects from our permanent and education collections. The museum also provides access to its collections to both scholarly endeavors and the greater public by actively participating with the general public, academia and the greater museum community by lending works and/or entire exhibitions from its collections to appropriate and approved lenders world-wide.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The income from the endowment account is to be utilized for the exhibition, development, and curatorial projects that benefit or create opportunities for emerging and mid-career artists, for acquisitions of art by emerging and mid-career artist's for the permanent collection, and for publications and catalogs supporting or documenting exhibitions or contemporary projects by emerging or mid-career artists. The William Randolph Hearst endowment fund income is used for education purposes.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Museum has adopted the provisions of FASB Accounting Standards Codification Topic ASC 740-10 (previously Financial Interpretation No. 48, Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes), on June 30, 2010. The implementation of this standard had no impact on the financial statements nor has the Museum recorded any liability related to uncertain tax provisions. The Museum will recognize future accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in income tax expense if incurred. The Museum is no longer subject to Federal tax examinations by tax authorities for years before 2007 and state examinations for years before 2007.
Special Events Expenses Recorded in Expenses for Financial Statements: -22084. Rental Expenses recorded in expenses for financial statements: -24003.
Special Events Expenses Deducted on line 9b: 22084. Rental Expenses recorded in expenses for financial statements: 24003.

IRS990ScheduleG.GamingManagerServicesProvided: Staffing, site management, personnel management, negotiations with vendors, overall fiscal management of gaming operations, lobbying, marketing, advertising, community relations

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: The organization does not capitalize donated works of art or recognize them as revenues or gains as permitted under SFAS 116. Donations need not be recognized if they are added to collections that are held for public exhibition, education, or research in furtherance of public service rather than financial gain; are protected, kept unencumbered, cared for, and preserved; and are subject to a policy that requires the proceeds from sales of collection items to be used to acquire other items for collections.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 6
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization has members. All members have the same voting rights. Any individual may become a member of the corporation by paying annual dues.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: At the annual meeting, the corporation's membership shall elect directors to be elected that year.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Management will review a draft copy of the Form 990. Following management's review of the 990, it will be presented to the board of directors and then presented to the full board. An electronic version of the completed Form 990 will be emailed to board members prior to the January 2011 board meeting.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization has a conflict of interest policy in place which covers the board of directors. If a conflict of interest exists, a board member leaves the room during the discussion in order to not influence any vote on the discussion and the board member abstains from voting on the issue with the conflict. Currently there is no formal process in place which requires an annual disclosure of conflicts, but the organization is working on putting this process in place. Conflicts will be reviewed by management and the board of directors and the board will determine whether a conflict of interest exists.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The board of directors approves the CEO's compensation. Comparability data from regional and local nonprofits of similar size are used for the compensation data. Written minutes were taken at the board meeting. This process was last completed in October 2008.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization makes its governing documents, conflict of interest policy and financial statements available to the public upon request.
